						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Sugar</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Two_other_uses&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Two other uses (page does not exist)">Template:Two other uses</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Redirect2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Redirect2 (page does not exist)">Template:Redirect2</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Good_article&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Good article (page does not exist)">Template:Good article</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi-indef</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Raw_sugar_closeup.jpg" title="File:Raw sugar closeup.jpg">File:Raw sugar closeup.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Closeup of raw (unrefined, unbleached) sugar</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nutritionalvalue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nutritionalvalue (page does not exist)">Template:Nutritionalvalue</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nutritionalvalue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nutritionalvalue (page does not exist)">Template:Nutritionalvalue</a>
</p><p><b>Sugar</b> is the generalized name for a class of chemically-related sweet-flavored substances, most of which are used as food. They are <a href="/wiki/Carbohydrate" title="Carbohydrate">carbohydrates</a>, composed of carbon, hydrogen and oxygen. There are various types of sugar derived from different sources. Simple sugars are called <a href="/wiki/Monosaccharide" title="Monosaccharide">monosaccharides</a> and include <a href="/wiki/Glucose" title="Glucose">glucose</a> (also known as dextrose), <a href="/wiki/Fructose" title="Fructose">fructose</a> and <a href="/wiki/Galactose" title="Galactose">galactose</a>. The table or granulated sugar most customarily used as food is <a href="/wiki/Sucrose" title="Sucrose">sucrose</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Disaccharide" title="Disaccharide">disaccharide</a> (in the body, sucrose hydrolyses into fructose and glucose). Other disaccharides include <a href="/wiki/Maltose" title="Maltose">maltose</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lactose" title="Lactose">lactose</a>. Chemically-different substances may also have a sweet taste, but are not classified as sugars. Some are used as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Low-calorie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Low-calorie (page does not exist)">lower-calorie</a> food substitutes for sugar described as <a href="/wiki/Artificial_sweetener" title="Artificial sweetener" class="mw-redirect">artificial sweeteners</a>.
</p><p>Sugars are found in the tissues of most plants, but are only present in sufficient concentrations for efficient extraction in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sugarcane&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sugarcane (page does not exist)">sugarcane</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sugar_beet" title="Sugar beet">sugar beet</a>. Sugarcane is a giant grass and has been cultivated in tropical climates in the Far East since ancient times. A great expansion in its production took place in the 18th century with the layout of sugar plantations in the West Indies and Americas. This was the first time that sugar became available to the common people who previously had to rely on honey to sweeten foods. Sugar beet is a root crop, is cultivated in cooler climates, and became a major source of sugar in the 19th century when methods for extracting the sugar became available. Sugar production and trade have changed the course of human history in many ways. It influenced the formation of colonies, the perpetuation of <a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">slavery</a>, the transition to indentured labour, the migration of peoples, wars between sugar trade-controlling nations in the 19th century, and the ethnic composition and political structure of the new world.
</p><p>The world produced about 168 million tonnes of sugar in 2011. The average person consumes about 24 kilograms of sugar each year (33.1&#160;kg in industrialised countries), equivalent to over 260 food calories per person, per day.
</p><p>Since the latter part of the twentieth century, it has been questioned whether a diet high in sugars, especially refined sugars, is bad for human health. Sugar has been linked to obesity, and suspected of, or fully implicated as a cause in the occurrence of diabetes, cardiovascular disease, dementia, macular degeneration and tooth decay. Numerous studies have been undertaken to try to clarify the position, but with varying results, mainly because of the difficulty of finding populations for use as controls that do not consume, or are largely free of any sugar consumption.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Myrmicaria_brunnea.jpg" title="File:Myrmicaria brunnea.jpg">File:Myrmicaria brunnea.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Ant" title="Ant">Ant</a> feeding on sugar crystals</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Etymology" title="Etymology">etymology</a> reflects the spread of the commodity. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English language (page does not exist)">English</a> word "sugar"<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> originates from the <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a> word <span lang="ar">سكر</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> <i>sukkar</i> which came from the <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a> <span lang="fa">شکر</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> <i>shekar</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
itself derived from <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> <i>शर्करा</i> <i>śarkarā</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-Hassan_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hassan-3">[3]</a></sup> which originated from <a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil</a> <i>சக்கரை</i> <i>Sakkarai</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup>  It most probably came to England by way of Italian merchants. The contemporary Italian word is <i>zucchero</i>, whereas the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a> words, <i>azúcar</i> and <i>açúcar</i> respectively, have kept a trace of the Arabic definite article. The Old French word is <i>zuchre</i> – contemporary French <i>sucre</i>. The earliest <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a> word attested is σάκχαρις (<i>sákkʰaris</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> A satisfactory <i>pedigree</i> explaining the spread of the word has yet to be done. The English word <i><a href="/wiki/Jaggery" title="Jaggery">jaggery</a></i>, a coarse brown sugar made from date palm sap or sugar cane juice, has a similar etymological origin; Portuguese <i>xagara</i> or <i>jagara</i>, derived from <a href="/wiki/Malayalam" title="Malayalam">Malayalam</a> <i>cakkarā</i> from the Sanskrit <i>śarkarā</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ancient_times_and_Middle_Ages">Ancient times and Middle Ages</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Canaviais_Sao_Paulo_01_2008_06.jpg" title="File:Canaviais Sao Paulo 01 2008 06.jpg">File:Canaviais Sao Paulo 01 2008 06.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Sugar_cane" title="Sugar cane" class="mw-redirect">Sugar cane</a> plantation</div></div></div>
<p>Sugar has been produced in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_subcontinent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian subcontinent (page does not exist)">Indian subcontinent</a><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> since ancient times. It was not plentiful or cheap in early times and <a href="/wiki/Honey" title="Honey">honey</a> was more often used for sweetening in most parts of the world. Originally, people chewed raw sugarcane to extract its sweetness. Sugarcane was a native of tropical <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Asia (page does not exist)">South Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kiple_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kiple-9">[9]</a></sup> Different species seem to have originated from different locations with <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saccharum_barberi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saccharum barberi (page does not exist)">Saccharum barberi</a></i> originating in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saccharum_edule&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saccharum edule (page does not exist)">S. edule</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saccharum_officinarum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saccharum officinarum (page does not exist)">S. officinarum</a></i> coming from <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Guinea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Guinea (page does not exist)">New Guinea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kiple_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kiple-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Sharpe_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sharpe-10">[10]</a></sup> One of the earliest historical references to sugarcane is in Chinese manuscripts dating back to 8th century BC which mention the fact that the use of sugarcane originated in India.<sup id="cite_ref-gr1_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gr1-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sugar remained relatively unimportant until the Indians discovered methods of turning <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sugarcane_juice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sugarcane juice (page does not exist)">sugarcane juice</a> into granulated crystals that were easier to store and to transport.<sup id="cite_ref-Adas_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Adas-12">[12]</a></sup> Crystallized sugar was discovered by the time of the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_dynasty" title="Gupta dynasty" class="mw-redirect">Imperial Guptas</a>, around 5th century AD.<sup id="cite_ref-Adas_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Adas-12">[12]</a></sup> In the local Indian language, these crystals were called <i>khanda</i> (<a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a>:खण्ड,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IAST&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IAST (page does not exist)">Template:IAST</a>) which is the source of the word <i>candy</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>Indian sailors, who carried <a href="/w/index.php?title=Clarified_butter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Clarified butter (page does not exist)">clarified butter</a> and sugar as supplies, introduced knowledge of sugar on the various <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trade_routes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trade routes (page does not exist)">trade routes</a> they travelled.<sup id="cite_ref-Adas_12-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Adas-12">[12]</a></sup> Buddhist monks, as they travelled around, brought sugar crystallization methods to China.<sup id="cite_ref-Kieschnick1_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kieschnick1-14">[14]</a></sup> During the reign of <a href="/wiki/Harsha" title="Harsha">Harsha</a> (r. 606–647) in <a href="/wiki/North_India" title="North India">North India</a>, Indian envoys in <a href="/wiki/Tang_Dynasty" title="Tang Dynasty">Tang China</a> taught methods of cultivating sugarcane after <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Taizong_of_Tang" title="Emperor Taizong of Tang">Emperor Taizong of Tang</a> (r. 626–649) made his interest in sugar known. China then established its first <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sugarcane&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sugarcane (page does not exist)">sugarcane</a> plantations in the seventh century.<sup id="cite_ref-sen_38_40_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sen_38_40-15">[15]</a></sup> Chinese documents confirm at least two missions to India, initiated in 647 AD, to obtain technology for sugar-refining.<sup id="cite_ref-Kieschnick11_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kieschnick11-16">[16]</a></sup> In South Asia, the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a> and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, sugar became a staple of cooking and <a href="/wiki/Dessert" title="Dessert">desserts</a>.
</p><p>The triumphant progress of <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> was halted on the banks of the <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">Indus River</a> by the refusal of his troops to go further east. They saw people in the Indian subcontinent growing sugarcane and making <i>granulated, salt-like sweet powder</i>, locally called <i>Sharkara</i> (<a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a>:शर्करा,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IAST&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IAST (page does not exist)">Template:IAST</a>), pronounced as saccharum (ζάκχαρι). On their return journey, the <a href="/wiki/Macedonia_(region)" title="Macedonia (region)">Macedonian</a> soldiers carried the "honey bearing reeds" home with them. Sugarcane remained a little-known crop in Europe for over a millennium, sugar a rare commodity, and traders of sugar wealthy.<sup id="cite_ref-gr1_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gr1-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Crusades&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crusades (page does not exist)">Crusaders</a> brought sugar home with them to Europe after their campaigns in the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Land" title="Holy Land">Holy Land</a>, where they encountered caravans carrying "sweet salt". Early in the 12th century, Venice acquired some villages near <a href="/wiki/Tyre,_Lebanon" title="Tyre, Lebanon">Tyre</a> and set up estates to produce sugar for export to Europe, where it supplemented honey which had previously been the only available sweetener.<sup id="cite_ref-Ponting_2000_481_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ponting_2000_481-17">[17]</a></sup>
Crusade chronicler <a href="/wiki/William_of_Tyre" title="William of Tyre">William of Tyre</a>, writing in the late 12th century, described sugar as "very necessary for the use and health of mankind".<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> In the 15th century, <a href="/wiki/Venice" title="Venice">Venice</a> was the chief sugar refining and distribution centre in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-gr1_11-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gr1-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_history">Modern history</span></h3>
<p>In August 1492, <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a> stopped at <a href="/wiki/La_Gomera" title="La Gomera">La Gomera</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Canary_Islands" title="Canary Islands">Canary Islands</a>, for wine and water, intending to stay only four days. He became romantically involved with the governor of the island, Beatriz de Bobadilla y Ossorio, and stayed a month. When he finally sailed, she gave him cuttings of sugarcane, which became the first to reach the New World.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sugar was a luxury in Europe prior to the 18th century, when it became more widely available. It then became popular and by the 19th century, sugar became considered a necessity. This evolution of taste and demand for sugar as an essential food ingredient unleashed major economic and social changes.<sup id="cite_ref-mintz_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mintz-20">[20]</a></sup> It drove, in part, colonization of tropical islands and nations where labor-intensive sugarcane plantations and sugar manufacturing could thrive. The demand for cheap labor to perform the hard work involved in its cultivation and processing increased the demand for the slave trade from Africa (in particular West Africa). After slavery was abolished, there was high demand for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indentured_labor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indentured labor (page does not exist)">indentured laborers</a> from South Asia (in particular India).<sup id="cite_ref-britain1_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britain1-21">[21]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Millions of slave and indentured laborers were brought into the Caribbean and the Americas, Indian Ocean colonies, southeast Asia, Pacific Islands, and East Africa and Natal. The modern ethnic mix of many nations that have been settled in the last two centuries has been influenced by the demand for sugar.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sugar also led to some industrialization of former colonies. For example, Lieutenant J. Paterson, of the Bengal establishment, persuaded the British Government that sugar cane could be cultivated in British India with many advantages and at less expense than in the West Indies. As a result, a number of sugar factories were established in <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">Bihar</a> in eastern India.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, sugar beet production increased in continental Europe because of the difficulty of importing sugar when shipping was subject to <a href="/wiki/Blockade" title="Blockade">blockade</a>. By 1880, the sugar beet was the main source of sugar in Europe. It was cultivated in Lincolnshire and other parts of England, although the United Kingdom continued to import the main part of its sugar from its colonies.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>Until the late nineteenth century, sugar was purchased in <a href="/wiki/Sugarloaf" title="Sugarloaf">loaves</a>, which had to be cut using implements called <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sugar_nips&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sugar nips (page does not exist)">Sugar nips</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> In later years, granulated sugar was more usually sold in bags.
</p><p>Sugar cubes were produced in the nineteenth century. The first inventor of a process to make sugar in cube form was <a href="/wiki/Moravia" title="Moravia">Moravian</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakub_Kry%C5%A1tof_Rad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakub Kryštof Rad (page does not exist)">Jakub Kryštof Rad</a>, director of a sugar company in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Da%C4%8Dice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dačice (page does not exist)">Dačice</a>. He began sugar cube production after being granted a five-year patent for the invention on January 23, 1843. <a href="/wiki/Henry_Tate" title="Henry Tate">Henry Tate</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tate_%26_Lyle" title="Tate &amp; Lyle">Tate &amp; Lyle</a> was another early manufacturer of sugar cubes at his refineries in Liverpool and London. Tate purchased a patent for sugar cube manufacture from German <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eugen_Langen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eugen Langen (page does not exist)">Eugen Langen</a>, who in 1872 had invented a different method of processing of sugar cubes.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Chemistry">Chemistry</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Saccharose.svg" title="File:Saccharose.svg">File:Saccharose.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Sucrose" title="Sucrose">Sucrose</a>: a disaccharide of <a href="/wiki/Glucose" title="Glucose">glucose</a> (left) and <a href="/wiki/Fructose" title="Fructose">fructose</a> (right), important molecules in the body.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Scientifically, <i>sugar</i> loosely refers to a number of carbohydrates, such as monosaccharides, disaccharides, or <a href="/wiki/Oligosaccharides" title="Oligosaccharides" class="mw-redirect">oligosaccharides</a>. Monosaccharides are also called "simple sugars," the most important being glucose. Almost all sugars have the formula <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> (n is between 3 and 7). Glucose has the <a href="/wiki/Molecular_formula" title="Molecular formula" class="mw-redirect">molecular formula</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>. The names of typical sugars end with "-ose," as in "glucose", "dextrose", and "fructose". Sometimes such words may also refer to any types of <a href="/wiki/Carbohydrates" title="Carbohydrates" class="mw-redirect">carbohydrates</a> soluble in <a href="/wiki/Water" title="Water">water</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Open-chain_compound" title="Open-chain compound">acyclic</a> mono- and disaccharides contain either <a href="/wiki/Aldehyde" title="Aldehyde">aldehyde</a> groups or <a href="/wiki/Ketone" title="Ketone">ketone</a> groups. These <a href="/wiki/Carbonyl" title="Carbonyl">carbon-oxygen</a> double bonds (C=O) are the reactive centers. All saccharides with more than one ring in their structure result from two or more monosaccharides joined by <a href="/wiki/Glycosidic_bond" title="Glycosidic bond">glycosidic bonds</a> with the resultant loss of a molecule of water (H<sub>2</sub>O) per bond.<sup id="cite_ref-Pigman_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pigman-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sugar_2xmacro.jpg" title="File:Sugar 2xmacro.jpg">File:Sugar 2xmacro.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Magnification of grains of refined <a href="/wiki/Sucrose" title="Sucrose">sucrose</a>, the most common free sugar</div></div></div>
<p>Monosaccharides in a closed-chain form can form glycosidic bonds with other monosaccharides, creating disaccharides (such as sucrose) and polysaccharides (such as starch). <a href="/wiki/Enzymes" title="Enzymes" class="mw-redirect">Enzymes</a> must hydrolyze or otherwise break these glycosidic bonds before such compounds become <a href="/wiki/Metabolism" title="Metabolism">metabolized</a>. After digestion and absorption the principal monosaccharides present in the blood and internal tissues include glucose, fructose, and galactose. Many pentoses and hexoses can form <a href="/wiki/Ring_structure" title="Ring structure" class="mw-redirect">ring structures</a>. In these closed-chain forms, the aldehyde or ketone group remains non-free, so many of the reactions typical of these groups cannot occur. Glucose in solution exists mostly in the ring form at <a href="/wiki/Chemical_equilibrium" title="Chemical equilibrium">equilibrium</a>, with less than 0.1% of the molecules in the open-chain form.<sup id="cite_ref-Pigman_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pigman-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Natural_polymers_of_sugars">Natural polymers of sugars</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Biopolymer" title="Biopolymer">Biopolymers</a> of sugars are common in nature. Through photosynthesis plants produce glucose, which has the formula <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>, and convert it for storage as an energy reserve in the form of other carbohydrates such as starch, or (as in cane and beet) as sucrose, with the chemical formula <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>. Starch, consisting of two different polymers of glucose, is a readily degradable form of chemical <a href="/wiki/Potential_energy" title="Potential energy">energy</a> stored by <a href="/wiki/Cell_(biology)" title="Cell (biology)">cells</a>, and can be converted to other types of energy.<sup id="cite_ref-Pigman_31-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pigman-31">[31]</a></sup> Another polymer of glucose is cellulose which is a linear chain composed of several hundred or thousand glucose units. It is used by plants as a structural component in their cell walls. Humans can only digest cellulose to a very limited extent, though <a href="/wiki/Ruminant" title="Ruminant">ruminants</a> can do so with the help of <a href="/wiki/Symbiosis" title="Symbiosis">symbiotic</a> bacteria in their gut.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/DNA" title="DNA">DNA</a> and <a href="/wiki/RNA" title="RNA">RNA</a> are built up of the monosaccharides <a href="/wiki/Deoxyribose" title="Deoxyribose">deoxyribose</a> and  <a href="/wiki/Ribose" title="Ribose">ribose</a> respectively. Deoxyribose has the formula C<sub>5</sub>H<sub>10</sub>O<sub>4</sub> and ribose the formula C<sub>5</sub>H<sub>10</sub>O<sub>5</sub>.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Flammability">Flammability</span></h3>
<p>Sugar is an organic substance that burns easily upon exposure to an open flame. Because of this, the handling of sugar presents a risk for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dust_explosion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dust explosion (page does not exist)">dust explosion</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_Georgia_sugar_refinery_explosion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 Georgia sugar refinery explosion (page does not exist)">2008 Georgia sugar refinery explosion</a>, which resulted in 14 deaths, 40 injured, and more than half of the facility's destruction, was caused by the ignition of sugar dust. The fire spread rapidly due to the level of sugar dust contamination throughout the facility, including several piles of indisposed sugar. A specialized <a href="/wiki/Foam" title="Foam">foam</a> truck had to be called in to put out the silo fires, because the sugar inside was burning at 4,000°F.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Types_of_sugar">Types of sugar</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Monosaccharides">Monosaccharides</span></h3>
<p>Glucose, fructose and galactose are all simple sugars, <a href="/wiki/Monosaccharide" title="Monosaccharide">monosaccharides</a>, with the general formula C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub>. They have five hydroxyl groups (−OH) and a carbonyl group (C=O) and are cyclic when dissolved in water. They each exist as several <a href="/w/index.php?title=Isomer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Isomer (page does not exist)">isomers</a> with dextro- and laevo-rotatory forms which cause polarized light to diverge to the right or the left.<sup id="cite_ref-Manual_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Manual-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p><b>Glucose</b>, dextrose or grape sugar occurs naturally in fruits and plant juices and is the primary product of <a href="/wiki/Photosynthesis" title="Photosynthesis">photosynthesis</a>. Most ingested carbohydrates are converted into glucose during digestion and it is the form of sugar that is transported around the bodies of animals in the bloodstream. It can be manufactured from starch by the addition of enzymes or in the presence of acids. Glucose syrup is a liquid form of glucose that is widely used in the manufacture of foodstuffs. It can be manufactured from starch by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Enzymatic_hydrolysis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Enzymatic hydrolysis (page does not exist)">enzymatic hydrolysis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p><p><b>Fructose</b> or fruit sugar occurs naturally in fruits, some root vegetables, cane sugar and honey and is the sweetest of the sugars. It is one of the components of sucrose or table sugar. It is used as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=High-fructose_corn_syrup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="High-fructose corn syrup (page does not exist)">high fructose syrup</a> which is manufactured from hydrolized corn starch which has been processed to yield <a href="/wiki/Corn_syrup" title="Corn syrup">corn syrup</a>, with enzymes then added to convert part of the glucose into fructose.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p><p><b>Galactose</b> does not generally occur in the free state but is a constituent with glucose of the disaccharide <a href="/wiki/Lactose" title="Lactose">lactose</a> or milk sugar. It is less sweet than glucose. It is a component of the antigens found on the surface of <a href="/wiki/Red_blood_cell" title="Red blood cell">red blood cells</a> that determine <a href="/wiki/ABO_blood_group_system" title="ABO blood group system">blood groups</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Raven_and_Johnson_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Raven_and_Johnson-37">[37]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Disaccharides">Disaccharides</span></h3>
<p>Sucrose, maltose and lactose are all compound sugars, <a href="/wiki/Disaccharide" title="Disaccharide">disaccharides</a>, with the general formula C<sub>12</sub>H<sub>22</sub>O<sub>11</sub>. They are formed by the combination of two monosaccharide molecules with the exclusion of a molecule of water.<sup id="cite_ref-Manual_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Manual-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p><b><a href="/wiki/Sucrose" title="Sucrose">Sucrose</a></b> is found in the stems of sugar cane and roots of sugar beet. It also occurs naturally alongside fructose and glucose in other plants, particularly fruits and some roots such as carrots. The different proportions of sugars found in these foods determines the range of sweetness experienced when eating them.<sup id="cite_ref-Manual_34-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Manual-34">[34]</a></sup> A molecule of sucrose is formed by the combination of a molecule of glucose with a molecule of fructose. After being eaten, sucrose is split into its constituent parts during digestion by a number of enzymes known as <a href="/wiki/Sucrase" title="Sucrase">sucrases</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p><b><a href="/wiki/Maltose" title="Maltose">Maltose</a></b> is formed during the germination of certain grains, most notably <a href="/w/index.php?title=Barley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barley (page does not exist)">barley</a> which is converted into <a href="/wiki/Malt" title="Malt">malt</a>, the source of the sugar's name. A molecule of maltose is formed by the combination of two molecules of glucose. It is less sweet than glucose, fructose or sucrose.<sup id="cite_ref-Manual_34-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Manual-34">[34]</a></sup> It is formed in the body during the digestion of starch by the enzyme <a href="/wiki/Amylase" title="Amylase">amylase</a> and is itself broken down during digestion by the enzyme <a href="/wiki/Maltase" title="Maltase">maltase</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p><b><a href="/wiki/Lactose" title="Lactose">Lactose</a></b> is the naturally occurring sugar found in milk. A molecule of lactose is formed by the combination of a molecule of galactose with a molecule of glucose. It is broken down when consumed into its constituent parts by the enzyme <a href="/wiki/Lactase" title="Lactase">lactase</a> during digestion. Children have this enzyme but some adults no longer form it and they are unable to digest lactose.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Production">Production</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sugar_beet">Sugar beet</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Packed_sugar_Slutsk.jpg" title="File:Packed sugar Slutsk.jpg">File:Packed sugar Slutsk.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A pack of sugar made of sugar beet.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Sugar_beet" title="Sugar beet">Sugar beet</a> (<i>Beta vulgaris</i>) is a <a href="/wiki/Biennial_plant" title="Biennial plant">biennial plant</a><sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> in the <a href="/wiki/Family_(biology)" title="Family (biology)">Family</a> <a href="/wiki/Amaranthaceae" title="Amaranthaceae">Amaranthaceae</a>, the tuberous root of which contains a high proportion of sucrose. It is cultivated in temperate regions with adequate rainfall and requires a fertile soil. The crop is harvested mechanically in the autumn and the crown of leaves and excess soil removed. The roots do not deteriorate rapidly and may be left in a clamp in the field for some weeks before being transported to the processing plant. Here the crop is washed and sliced and the sugar extracted by diffusion. <a href="/wiki/Milk_of_lime" title="Milk of lime" class="mw-redirect">Milk of lime</a> is added to the raw juice  and <a href="/wiki/Carbonatation" title="Carbonatation">carbonatated</a> in a number of stages in order to purify it. Water is evaporated by boiling the syrup under a vacuum. The syrup is then cooled and seeded with sugar crystals. The white sugar which crystallizes out can be separated in a centrifuge and dried. It requires no further refining.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sugarcane">Sugarcane</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sugarcane&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sugarcane (page does not exist)">Sugarcane</a> (<i>Saccharum spp.</i>) is a <a href="/wiki/Perennial_plant" title="Perennial plant">perennial</a> grass in the family <a href="/wiki/Poaceae" title="Poaceae">Poaceae</a>. It is cultivated in tropical and sub-tropical regions for the sucrose that is found in its stems. It requires a frost-free climate with sufficient rainfall during the growing season to make full use of the plant's great growth potential. The crop is harvested mechanically or by hand, chopped into lengths and conveyed rapidly to the processing plant. Here it is either milled and the juice extracted with water or the sugar is extracted by diffusion. The juice is then clarified with <a href="/wiki/Calcium_hydroxide" title="Calcium hydroxide">lime</a> and heated to kill <a href="/wiki/Enzyme" title="Enzyme">enzymes</a>. The resulting thin syrup is concentrated in a series of evaporators after which further water is removed by evaporation in vacuum containers. The resulting <a href="/wiki/Supersaturation" title="Supersaturation">supersaturated</a> solution is seeded with sugar crystals and the sugar crystallizes out, is separated from the fluid and dried. <a href="/wiki/Molasses" title="Molasses">Molasses</a> is a by-product of the process and the fiber from the stems, known as <a href="/wiki/Bagasse" title="Bagasse">bagasse</a>, is burned to provide energy for the sugar extraction process. The crystals of raw sugar have a sticky brown coating and can either be used as they are or can be bleached by <a href="/wiki/Sulphur_dioxide" title="Sulphur dioxide" class="mw-redirect">sulphur dioxide</a> or treated in a <a href="/wiki/Carbonatation" title="Carbonatation">carbonatation</a> process to produce a whiter product.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Refining">Refining</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sucre_blanc_cassonade_complet_rapadura.jpg" title="File:Sucre blanc cassonade complet rapadura.jpg">File:Sucre blanc cassonade complet rapadura.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sugars; clockwise from top left: <center>White refined, unrefined,<br /> brown, unprocessed cane</center></div></div></div>
<p>Cane sugar requires further processing to provide the free-flowing white table sugar required by the consumer. The sugar may be transported in bulk to the country where it will be used and the refining process often takes place there. The first stage is known as affination and involves immersing the sugar crystals in a concentrated syrup which softens and removes the sticky brown coating without dissolving them. The crystals are then separated from the liquor and dissolved in water. The resulting syrup is either treated by a <a href="/wiki/Carbonatation" title="Carbonatation">carbonatation</a> or a phosphatation process. Both involve the precipitation of a fine solid in the syrup and when this is filtered out, a lot of the impurities are removed at the same time. Removal of colour is achieved by either using a granular <a href="/wiki/Activated_carbon" title="Activated carbon">activated carbon</a> or an <a href="/wiki/Ion-exchange_resin" title="Ion-exchange resin">ion-exchange resin</a>. The sugar syrup is concentrated by boiling and then cooled and seeded with sugar crystals causing the sugar to crystallize out. The liquor is spun in a centrifuge and the white crystals are dried in hot air, ready to be packaged or used. The surplus liquor is made into refiners' molasses.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
The <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Commission_for_Uniform_Methods_of_Sugar_Analysis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Commission for Uniform Methods of Sugar Analysis (page does not exist)">International Commission for Uniform Methods of Sugar Analysis</a> sets standards for the measurement of the purity of refined sugar, known as ICUMSA numbers; lower numbers indicate a higher level of purity in the refined sugar.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Producing_countries">Producing countries</span></h3>
<p>The five largest producers of sugar in 2011 were <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>, India, the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, China and <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a>. In the same year, the largest exporter of sugar was Brazil, distantly followed by Thailand, Australia and India. The largest importers were the European Union, United States and Indonesia. Currently, Brazil has the highest <a href="/wiki/Per_capita" title="Per capita">per capita</a> consumption of sugar, followed by Australia, Thailand and the European Union.<sup id="cite_ref-Sugar:_World_Markets_and_Trade_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sugar:_World_Markets_and_Trade-47">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-consumption_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-consumption-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Forms_and_uses">Forms and uses</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rock-Candy-Closeup.jpg" title="File:Rock-Candy-Closeup.jpg">File:Rock-Candy-Closeup.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rock candy crystallised out of a <a href="/wiki/Supersaturation" title="Supersaturation">supersaturated sugar solution</a></div></div></div>
<p>Granulated sugars are used at the table to sprinkle on foods and to sweeten hot drinks and in home baking to add sweetness and texture to cooked products. They are also used as a preservative to prevent micro-organisms from growing and perishable food from spoiling as in jams, marmalades and candied fruits.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>Milled sugars are ground to a fine powder. They are used as <a href="/wiki/Powdered_sugar" title="Powdered sugar">icing sugar</a>, for dusting foods and in baking and confectionery.<sup id="cite_ref-BS_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BS-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>Screened sugars are crystalline products separated according to the size of the grains. They are used for decorative table sugars, for blending in dry mixes and in baking and confectionery.<sup id="cite_ref-BS_50-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BS-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Brown_sugar" title="Brown sugar">Brown sugars</a> are granulated sugars with the grains coated in molasses to produce a light, dark or demerara sugar. They are used in baked goods, confectionery and toffees.<sup id="cite_ref-BS_50-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BS-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sugar cubes are white or brown granulated sugars pressed together in block shape. They are used to sweeten drinks.<sup id="cite_ref-BS_50-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BS-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>Liquid sugars are strong syrups consisting of 67% granulated sugar dissolved in water. They are used in the food processing of a wide range of products including beverages, <a href="/wiki/Ice_cream" title="Ice cream">ice cream</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fruit_preserves&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fruit preserves (page does not exist)">jams</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BS_50-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BS-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Inverted_sugar_syrup" title="Inverted sugar syrup">Invert sugars</a> and syrups are blended to manufacturers specifications and are used in breads, cakes and beverages for adjusting sweetness, aiding moisture retention and avoiding crystallization of sugars.<sup id="cite_ref-BS_50-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BS-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Syrup" title="Syrup">Syrups</a> and <a href="/wiki/Treacle" title="Treacle">treacles</a> are dissolved invert sugars heated to develop the characteristic flavors. Treacles have added molasses. They are used in a range of baked goods and confectionery including toffees and <a href="/wiki/Licorice" title="Licorice" class="mw-redirect">licorice</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BS_50-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BS-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>Low calorie sugars and sweeteners are often made of <a href="/wiki/Maltodextrin" title="Maltodextrin">maltodextrin</a> with added sweeteners. Maltodextrin is an easily digestible synthetic <a href="/wiki/Polysaccharide" title="Polysaccharide">polysaccharide</a> consisting of short chains of glucose molecules and is made by the partial <a href="/wiki/Hydrolysis" title="Hydrolysis">hydrolysis</a> of starch. The added sweeteners are often <a href="/wiki/Aspartame" title="Aspartame">aspartame</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saccharin" title="Saccharin">saccharin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stevia" title="Stevia">stevia</a> or <a href="/wiki/Sucralose" title="Sucralose">sucralose</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Polyol" title="Polyol">Polyols</a> are <a href="/wiki/Sugar_alcohol" title="Sugar alcohol">sugar alcohols</a> and are used in chewing gums where a sweet flavor is required that lasts for a prolonged time in the mouth.<sup id="cite_ref-Union1990_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Union1990-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Winemaking" title="Winemaking">winemaking</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sugars_in_wine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sugars in wine (page does not exist)">fruit sugars</a> are converted into <a href="/wiki/Alcohol" title="Alcohol">alcohol</a> by a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_(wine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fermentation (wine) (page does not exist)">fermentation</a> process. If the <a href="/wiki/Must" title="Must">must</a> formed by pressing the fruit has a low sugar content, additional sugar may be added to raise the alcohol content of the wine in a process called <a href="/wiki/Chaptalization" title="Chaptalization">chaptalization</a>. In the production of sweet wines, fermentation may be halted before it has run its full course, leaving behind some <a href="/wiki/Residual_sugar" title="Residual sugar" class="mw-redirect">residual sugar</a> that gives the wine its sweet taste.<sup id="cite_ref-Oxford_pg_665-666_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oxford_pg_665-666-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Consumption">Consumption</span></h2>
<p>In most parts of the world, sugar is an important part of the human diet, making food more palatable and providing <a href="/wiki/Food_energy" title="Food energy">food energy</a>. After cereals and vegetable oils, sugar derived from sugar cane and beet provided more kilocalories per capita per day on average than other food groups.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=FAO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FAO (page does not exist)">FAO</a>, an average of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of sugar, equivalent to over 260 food calories per day, was consumed annually per person of all ages in the world in 1999. Even with rising human populations, sugar consumption is expected to increase to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> per person per year by 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-fao2002p_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fao2002p-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>Data collected in multiple nationwide surveys between 1999 and 2008 show that the intake of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Added_sugars&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Added sugars (page does not exist)">added sugars</a> has declined by 24 percent with declines occurring in all age, ethnic and income groups.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup>
</p>

In 2008, American per capita total consumption of sugar and sweeteners, exclusive of artificial sweeteners, equalled <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> per year. </p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_effects">Health effects</span></h2>
<p>Some studies involving the health impact of sugars are effectively inconclusive. The WHO and FAO meta studies have shown directly contrasting impacts of sugar in refined and unrefined forms<sup id="cite_ref-FAO_Expert_Consultation_2003_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FAO_Expert_Consultation_2003-60">[60]</a></sup> and since most studies do not use a population who are not consuming any "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Free_sugar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Free sugar (page does not exist)">free sugars</a>" at all, the baseline is effectively flawed. Hence there are articles such as <i><a href="/wiki/Consumer_Reports" title="Consumer Reports">Consumer Reports</a> on Health</i> that said in 2008, "Some of the supposed dietary dangers of sugar have been overblown. Many studies have debunked the idea that it causes hyperactivity, for example."<sup id="cite_ref-Consumers_Union_of_U.S_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Consumers_Union_of_U.S-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Blood_glucose_levels">Blood glucose levels</span></h3>
<p>It used to be believed that sugar raised <a href="/wiki/Blood_glucose" title="Blood glucose" class="mw-redirect">blood glucose</a> levels more quickly than did <a href="/wiki/Starch" title="Starch">starch</a> because of its simpler chemical structure. However, it turned out that white bread or French fries have the same effect on blood sugar as pure glucose, while fructose, although a simple carbohydrate, has a minimal effect on blood sugar. As a result, as far as blood sugar is concerned, carbohydrates are classified according to their <a href="/wiki/Glycemic_index" title="Glycemic index">glycemic index</a>, a system for measuring how quickly a food that is eaten raises blood sugar levels, and <a href="/wiki/Glycemic_load" title="Glycemic load">glycemic load</a>, which takes into account both the glycemic index and the amount of carbohydrate in the food.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> This has led to carbohydrate counting, a method used by diabetics for planning their meals.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Obesity_and_diabetes">Obesity and diabetes</span></h3>
<p>Studies on the link between sugars and diabetes are inconclusive, with some suggesting that eating excessive amounts of sugar does not increase the risk of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Diabetes_mellitus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diabetes mellitus (page does not exist)">diabetes</a>, although the extra calories from consuming large amounts of sugar can lead to <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">obesity</a>, which may itself increase the risk of developing this <a href="/wiki/Metabolic_disease" title="Metabolic disease" class="mw-redirect">metabolic disease</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dietetic_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dietetic-65">[65]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-diabetes_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-diabetes-68">[68]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> 
Other studies show correlation between refined sugar (free sugar) consumption and the onset of diabetes, and negative correlation with the consumption of <a href="/wiki/Dietary_fiber" title="Dietary fiber">fiber</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> These included a 2010 meta-analysis of eleven studies involving 310,819 participants and 15,043 cases of <a href="/wiki/Diabetes_mellitus_type_2" title="Diabetes mellitus type 2">type 2 diabetes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> 
This found that "SSBs (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweetened_beverage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweetened beverage (page does not exist)">sugar-sweetened beverages</a>) may increase the risk of <a href="/wiki/Metabolic_syndrome" title="Metabolic syndrome">metabolic syndrome</a> and type 2 diabetes not only through obesity but also by increasing dietary glycemic load, leading to insulin resistance, β-cell dysfunction, and inflammation".  As an overview to consumption related to chronic disease and obesity, the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a>'s independent meta-studies specifically distinguish free sugars ("all monosaccharides and disaccharides added to foods by the manufacturer, cook or consumer, plus sugars naturally present in honey, syrups and fruit juices") from sugars occurring naturally in food.  The reports prior to 2000 set the limits for free sugars at a maximum of 10% of carbohydrate intake, measured by energy, rather than mass, and since 2002<sup id="cite_ref-FAO_Expert_Consultation_2003_60-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FAO_Expert_Consultation_2003-60">[60]</a></sup> have aimed for a level across the entire population of less than 10%. The consultation committee recognized that this goal is "controversial. However, the Consultation considered that the studies showing no effect of free sugars on excess weight have limitations."<sup id="cite_ref-FAO_Expert_Consultation_2003_60-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FAO_Expert_Consultation_2003-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cardiovascular_disease">Cardiovascular disease</span></h3>
<p>A number of studies in animals have suggested that chronic consumption of refined sugars can contribute to metabolic and <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease" title="Cardiovascular disease">cardiovascular dysfunction</a>.  Some experts have suggested that refined fructose is more damaging than refined glucose in terms of cardiovascular risk.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup>  Cardiac performance has been shown to be impaired by switching from a carbohydrate diet including fiber to a high-carbohydrate diet.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup>
Switching from saturated <a href="/wiki/Fatty_acid" title="Fatty acid">fatty acids</a> to carbohydrates with high <a href="/wiki/Glycemic_index" title="Glycemic index">glycemic index</a> values shows a statistically-significant increase in the risk of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Myocardial_infarction&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Myocardial infarction (page does not exist)">myocardial infarction</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> Other studies have shown that the risk of developing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Coronary_disease&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Coronary disease (page does not exist)">coronary heart disease</a> is decreased by adopting a diet high in polyunsaturated fatty acids but low in sugar whereas a low fat, high carbohydrate diet brings no reduction. This suggests that consuming a diet with a high <a href="/wiki/Glycemic_load" title="Glycemic load">glycemic load</a> typical of the "<a href="/wiki/Junk_food" title="Junk food">junk food</a>" diet, is strongly associated with an increased risk of developing coronary heart disease.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p><p>The consumption of added sugars has been positively associated with multiple measures known to increase cardiovascular disease risk amongst adolescents as well as adults.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup>
Studies are suggesting that the impact of refined carbohydrates or high glycemic load carbohydrates are more significant than the impact of saturated fatty acids on cardiovascular disease.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>
A high dietary intake of sugar (in this case, sucrose or disaccharide) can substantially increase the risk of heart and vascular diseases. According to a Swedish study of <span class="nowrap">4301 people</span> undertaken by <a href="/wiki/Lund_University" title="Lund University">Lund University</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malm%C3%B6_University_College&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Malmö University College (page does not exist)">Malmö University College</a>, sugar was associated with higher levels of bad <a href="/w/index.php?title=Blood_lipids&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blood lipids (page does not exist)">blood lipids</a>, causing a high level of small and medium <a href="/wiki/Low-density_lipoprotein" title="Low-density lipoprotein">low-density lipoprotein</a> (LDL) and reduced <a href="/wiki/High-density_lipoprotein" title="High-density lipoprotein">high-density lipoprotein</a> (HDL). In contrast, the amount of fat eaten did not affect the level of blood fats. As a side note, moderate quantities of <a href="/wiki/Ethanol" title="Ethanol">alcohol</a> and protein were linked to an increase in the good HDL blood fat.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Alzheimer.27s_disease">Alzheimer's disease</span></h3>
<p>It is suggested that <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alzheimer%27s_disease&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alzheimer's disease (page does not exist)">Alzheimer's disease</a> is linked with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_pattern_diet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western pattern diet (page does not exist)">western diet</a>, which is characterised by high intakes of <a href="/wiki/Red_meat" title="Red meat">red meat</a>, sugary foods, high-fat foods and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Refined_grains&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Refined grains (page does not exist)">refined grains</a>.  It has been hypothesized that <a href="/wiki/Dementia" title="Dementia">dementia</a> could be prevented by taking mono-supplements of specific vitamins or drugs, but studies have shown that this approach does not show appreciable results.<sup id="cite_ref-Berrino2002_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Berrino2002-83">[83]</a></sup>
</p><p>Dietary pattern analysis considers overall eating patterns, comparing diets of people with Alzheimer's disease to diets of healthy controls using factor analysis. This analysis shows a major eating pattern for those with Alzheimer's characterised by a high intake of meat, butter, high-fat dairy products, eggs, and refined sugar, while the major eating pattern for those without Alzheimer's was characterised by a high intake of grains and vegetables.<sup id="cite_ref-Gustaw-rothenberg2009_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gustaw-rothenberg2009-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>One group of experimenters compared a normal rodent diet (19% protein, 5% fat and 60% complex carbohydrate) with free access to water against the same diet but with free access to a 10% sucrose solution.  The experimental results underscore the potential role of dietary sugar in the <a href="/wiki/Pathogenesis" title="Pathogenesis">pathogenesis</a> of Alzheimer's disease and suggest that controlling the consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages may be an effective way to curtail the risk of developing the disease.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Macular_degeneration">Macular degeneration</span></h3>
<p>There are links between free sugar consumption and <a href="/wiki/Macular_degeneration" title="Macular degeneration">macular degeneration</a> in older age.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tooth_decay">Tooth decay</span></h3>
<p>In regard to contributions to <a href="/wiki/Dental_caries" title="Dental caries">tooth decay</a>, the role of free sugars is also recommended to be below an absolute maximum of 10% of energy intake, with a minimum of zero.  There is "convincing evidence from human intervention studies, epidemiological studies, animal studies and experimental studies, for an association between the amount and frequency of free sugars intake and dental caries" while other sugars (complex carbohydrate) consumption is normally associated with a lower rate of dental caries.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-87">[87]</a></sup> Lower rates of tooth decay have been seen in individuals with <a href="/wiki/Hereditary_fructose_intolerance" title="Hereditary fructose intolerance">hereditary fructose intolerance</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-pmid19723928_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pmid19723928-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>Also, studies have shown that the consumption of sugar and starch have different impacts on oral health with the ingestion of starchy foods and fresh fruit being associated with low levels of dental caries.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_87-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-87">[87]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Addiction">Addiction</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Sugar addiction is the term for the relationship between sugar and the various aspects of food addiction including: "bingeing, withdrawal, craving and cross-sensitization".  Some scientists assert that consumption of <a href="/wiki/Sweets" title="Sweets" class="mw-redirect">sweets</a> or sugar could have a <a href="/wiki/Opioid_dependence" title="Opioid dependence">heroin addiction</a> like effect.<sup id="cite_ref-Avena-Rada-Hoebel_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Avena-Rada-Hoebel-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hyperactivity_misconception">Hyperactivity misconception</span></h3>
<p>There is a common notion that sugar leads to hyperactivity, particularly in children, but studies and meta-studies tend to disprove this."<sup id="cite_ref-Consumers_Union_of_U.S_61-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Consumers_Union_of_U.S-61">[61]</a></sup> Some articles and studies do refer to the increasing evidence supporting the links between refined sugar and hyperactivity.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> The WHO FAO meta-study suggests that such inconclusive results are to be expected when some studies do not effectively segregate or control for free sugars as opposed to sugars still in their natural form (entirely unrefined) while others do.<sup id="cite_ref-FAO_Expert_Consultation_2003_60-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FAO_Expert_Consultation_2003-60">[60]</a></sup> One study followed thirty-five 5-to-7-year-old boys who were reported by their mothers to be behaviorally "sugar sensitive". They were randomly assigned to experimental and control groups. In the experimental group, mothers were told that their children were fed sugar, and in the control group, mothers were told that their children received a placebo. In fact, all children actually received the placebo, but mothers in the sugar expectancy condition rated their children as significantly more hyperactive.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> This suggests that the real effect of sugar is that it increases worrying among parents with preconceived notions.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Medicinal_usage">Medicinal usage</span></h2>
<p>Sugar is effective in wound cleaning.<sup id="cite_ref-Sugar2013_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sugar2013-92">[92]</a></sup> In 2013, Murandu et al. found clinically that sugar is an antibiotic, and pouring granulated sugar on necrotic wounds can help ulcers heal faster.<sup id="cite_ref-Sugar20132_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sugar20132-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Measurements">Measurements</span></h2>
<p>Different culinary sugars have different densities due to differences in particle size and inclusion of moisture.
</p><p>The Domino Sugar Company has established the following volume to weight conversions:<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul>
<li>Brown sugar 1&#160;cup = 48 teaspoons ~ 195 g = 6.88&#160;oz
</li>
<li>Granular sugar 1&#160;cup = 48 teaspoons ~ 200 g = 7.06&#160;oz
</li>
<li>Powdered sugar 1&#160;cup = 48 teaspoons ~ 120 g = 4.23&#160;oz.
</li>
</ul>
<p>Bulk density<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul>
<li>Dextrose sugar 0.62 g/mL ( = 620&#160;kg/m^3)
</li>
<li>Granulated sugar 0.70 g/mL
</li>
<li>Powdered sugar 0.56 g/mL
</li>
<li>Beet sugar 0.80 g/mL
</li>
</ul>
